FacilityName: City of Harrisonburg, Tower Street Reservoir

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.) ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES:

The City of Harrisonburg uses chlorine gas for disinfection of the public drinking water.  The City remains committed to provide and/or exceed the necessary equipment and training, as required by all applicable federal and state regulations, for the safety and welfare of our employees and citizens. 

The City Public Utilities Department has had a written emergency action plan, for this site, since the late 1980's. This re-submission and certification again demonstrates the City's desire to remain in compliance with EPA's Risk Management program requirements (40 CFR part 68). The primary focus of our emergency action program is for efficient communication to the Harrisonburg Fire Department HAZMAT Unit, who is extensively trained for response and repair of chlorine leaks.  

B.) FACILITIES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED:

The purpose of this chlorination facility is to disinfect and maintain a state-required chlorine residual in the public drinking water distribution system for the City of Harrisonburg.  Chlorine gas, liquefied by pressure in chemical supplier tanks, is received by trucks and stored at the site, as described below.  

The Tower Street Reservoir site stores up to a maximum of six 1-ton containers for supplemental chlorination of 21 million gallons of stored potable water.  Chlorination is achieved at this site by the use of V-Notch chlorinators. The chlorine building houses chlorine cylinders, (2) V-notch chlorinators and process safety equipment. The facility is normally unmanned, however, qualified personnel visit and inspect the facility daily to observe the process parameters and evaluate the credibility of any alarms.

C.) THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS:

The City of Harrisonburg's Prevention Program has evolved over the past 30 years, with the guidance of the Virginia Health Department regulations, AWWA recommendations, E.P

.A. on-site visit and recommendations, and good engineering practices, keeping in focus the safety and welfare of our employees, citizens, and the environment.  

The Public Utilities Department believes that the following practices specifically enhance our prevention program.  



PROCEDURES AND EQUIPMENT:

1) Remote location features a lockable building, protected by a coded alarm system, with limited access to only authorized personnel.  

2) Employee training with local fire department, chlorine suppliers, and local seminars. 

3) Color-coded labeling of process components.  

4) Vacuum regulators used on each active container for automatic shut off in the event of a pipe or equipment leak.  

5) The entire reservoir site is fenced with 6' cyclone fence with three top strands of barbed wire and hardened locks on all gates.

6) Annual rebuild of vacuum regulators and chlorinators

7) Daily evaluation of process and written documentation of changes in chlorine feed rates & cylinder weights

8) Scales in place, to weigh active containers.

9) Four-ton hoist exists for container handling in the building.  

10) Special designed trailer equipped with 4-ton hydraulic hoist for handling containers from the storage area to the building.  

11) Automatic ventilation system, designed for three (3) air changes per minute in the building.  

12) Locally audible and visual chlorine leak detection and alarm unit (SCADA capable). 

13) Wind sock is visible from the entrance road of the property.  

14) SCBA and radio communications on site. Personnel equipped with cellular telephones. 

15) Continue to develop written operational procedures, hazard review and program auditing.

16) Random site perimeter observations day and night by the Harrisonburg Police Department.

17) Increased random inspections initiated in harmony with the National Security Alert Levels (indicated by color-code system)



PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE:

1) New gasket required with each cylinder change.  

2)

Check all connections for leaks with ammonia vapors.  

3) Annual rebuild of chlorinators, vacuum regulators, and heaters.  

4) Routine inspection of all equipment daily.  

D.) FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

This facility has had NO accidental releases of chlorine, with offsite consequences, in the past 5 years.  Minor vapor leaks do occur occasionally, during cylinder change outs.  However, we have not experienced a release condition that would create a toxic endpoint offsite.  

E.) THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

This facilities emergency response program is based on timely notification of the Harrisonburg Fire Department, who staffs a Hazardous Material Response Team, consisting of trained HAZMAT specialists and technicians who have proper equipment for mitigating chlorine leaks from 150 pound cylinders to 1-ton containers. The Harrisonburg Fire Department is a member of the Harrisonburg-Rockingham Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The Harrisonburg community has an active 911 and "Reverse 911" system. The "Reverse 911" system allows local emergency officials to notify area residents in the event of a chemical release or other emergency.

Specific Activities required of Public Utilities staff upon receipt of threat warning include:

1) Contact the Superintendent of Water Treatment or the Pump Assets/Operations Manager to form a site characterization team

2) Site team shall conduct a perimeter probing to monitor Cl2 source

Specific Activities required of Public Utilities staff upon confirmation of credible threat:

1) Contact 911 for Haz-Mat assistance

2) Contact National Response Center (1-800-424-8802) within 15 minutes

3) Contact Local Emergency Planning Commission (1-540-564-3010) within 15 minutes

4) Contact Virginia Department of Emergency Services (1-800-468-8892) within 15 minutes

5) Refer to the "Tower Street Reservoir Risk Management Plan"

Mitigation shall be referred to Haz-Mat.

F.) PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

At the Tower Stre

et Reservoir site a floating cover installed on the smallest reservoir has reduced the quantity of chlorine applied by approximately 30 percent.  The long-term capital outlay program targets replacement of both existing reservoirs at this site, with modern ground storage tanks. This endeavor could actually result in reducing the chlorine requirements at this site to a sodium hypochlorite disinfection system and/or the storage of gas chlorine below the regulated threshold quantity. The ultimate goal is to de-register this facility.

Our recent Vulnerability Assessment, submitted to EPA in accordance with the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 (Bioterrorism Act, PL 107-188), identifies existing and proposed countermeasures that enhance site security and thereby improve safety. The proposed countermeasures to be considered for funding in the future include:

* Card Key Badge & Vehicular Gate 

* Ptz Camera at Reservoirs

* Upgrade Fence at Reservoirs

* SCADA Annunciation of CL2 Detection to WTP

In addition, we continue to review options with the Harrisonburg Fire Department and chemical suppliers to provide additional, more comprehensive training to the personnel responsible for chlorine facilities and emergency responses.
